description: From French cynosure (“Ursa Minor; Polaris”), from Latin Cynosūra (“Ursa Minor”), from Ancient Greek Κυνόσουρα (Kunósoura, “Ursa Minor”, literally “dog’s tail”), from κυνός (kunós, “dog's”) + οὐρά (ourá, “tail”).

entries.meaning: (usually capitalized) Ursa Minor or Polaris, the North Star, used as a guide by navigators.
(figuratively) That which serves to guide or direct; a guiding star.
examples: let faith be your cynosure to walk by

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Something that is the center of attention; an object that serves as a focal point of attraction and admiration.
